verses.text: The LORD said to me, "Take a large scroll and write on it with an ordinary pen: 'Belonging to Maher-shalal-hash-baz.'"
verses.comment: God commands Isaiah to write a prophetic name symbolizing the coming rapid plunder of Israel's enemies. The use of a large scroll signifies a public and enduring witness.

verses.text: And I called in faithful witnesses—Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberechiah—to record this.
verses.comment: God instructs Isaiah to involve trusted, official witnesses, emphasizing the public and verifiable nature of prophecy in biblical tradition.

verses.text: I approached the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then the LORD said to me, "Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz."
verses.comment: Isaiah’s wife, called 'the prophetess,' shares in his prophetic mission. Their son's name means 'swift is the spoil, speedy is the prey,' predicting imminent judgment—a sign to all. Note the parallel to the sign-child in Isaiah 7:14, prefiguring the ultimate Emmanuel.

verses.text: For before the boy knows how to cry 'My father' or 'My mother,' the wealth of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria will be carried off by the king of Assyria."
verses.comment: Isaiah’s son is a living sign: swift is the coming judgment. The prophecy’s time frame (before the child can speak) shows God’s control over history and affirms the immediacy of His word.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to me again:
verses.comment: God’s continued direct communication with Isaiah shows His ongoing guidance of His people through chosen mediators.

verses.text: "Because this people has rejected the gently flowing waters of Shiloah, and rejoices in Rezin and the son of Remaliah,
verses.comment: The people’s rejection of 'Shiloah' (symbolic of God’s gentle guidance from Jerusalem) for military alliances reflects a spiritual failure to trust God’s provision—an image of preferring human power over divine grace.

verses.text: therefore, the Lord is about to bring against them the mighty, rushing waters of the River—the king of Assyria and all his glory. It will overflow all its channels and run over all its banks.
verses.comment: By refusing God’s quiet stream, Israel is overwhelmed by the destructive floodwaters of Assyria—judgment as consequence of spiritual disobedience. This image is repeated throughout scripture to signify God’s judgment but also His eventual restoration.

verses.text: It will sweep into Judah, flooding and passing through; it will reach up to the neck. Its outspread wings will cover the breadth of your land, O Immanuel."
verses.comment: 'Immanuel' (God with us) appears again, showing God’s continuing presence amid trial. The flood reaches Judah’s neck—it is not total destruction. The remnant principle is key in biblical faith: God's people are never ultimately abandoned.

verses.text: Raise the war cry, you peoples, and be shattered! Listen, all you distant nations. Prepare for battle, but you will be broken; prepare for battle, but you will be broken!
verses.comment: Despite the surrounding nations’ military power, God’s will prevails. This echoes Psalm 2, where nations plot in vain against God’s anointed.

verses.text: Devise your plan, but it will be thwarted; speak your word, but it will not stand, for God is with us.
verses.comment: God’s ultimate sovereignty is emphasized. 'God is with us'—Immanuel—foreshadows the New Testament revelation of God’s presence through Christ (see Matt. 1:23).

verses.text: For the LORD strongly spoke to me, grasping my hand and warning me not to walk in the way of this people, saying:
verses.comment: Isaiah’s prophetic calling demands separation from popular opinion, a model for all God's servants who must listen to divine wisdom over the crowd—a call repeated in both Old and New Testament discipleship.

verses.text: "Do not call conspiracy all that this people calls conspiracy; and do not fear what they fear or be terrified.
verses.comment: Believers are warned against succumbing to mass panic or conspiracies—security comes from faith, not from the world.

verses.text: The LORD of hosts—him you shall regard as holy, let him be your fear, and let him be your dread.
verses.comment: God alone should inspire reverent fear. The 'fear of the LORD' is the foundation of wisdom; only submission to God provides security.

verses.text: And he will become a sanctuary, but a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense to both houses of Israel, a trap and a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: God’s presence is life-giving for the faithful but judgment for the unfaithful. The language is picked up in the New Testament as a prophecy about Christ: He is the foundation stone, yet rejected by many—a spiritual and historical turning point.

verses.text: Many will stumble over it; they will fall and be broken; they will be snared and captured."
verses.comment: Rejection of God's cornerstone leads to ruin—a warning fulfilled in Christ’s ministry. See 1 Peter 2:8 for the apostolic interpretation.

verses.text: "Bind up the testimony; seal the instruction among my disciples."
verses.comment: A command to preserve God’s revelation among trustworthy followers ensures the integrity and preservation of sacred teaching—a concept foundational to Christian tradition.

verses.text: I will wait for the LORD, who is hiding his face from the house of Jacob, and I will hope in him.
verses.comment: True faith perseveres, trusting God even in times of apparent silence. Hebrews 2:13 reads this as Messianic: the suffering Servant’s confidence in the Father.

verses.text: Here am I and the children whom the LORD has given me; we are signs and wonders in Israel from the LORD of hosts, who dwells on Mount Zion.
verses.comment: Isaiah and his children are living signs of God’s sovereignty. Hebrews applies this to Christ and the Church, signifying God’s family as visible evidence of His redemptive plan.

verses.text: When they say to you, 'Inquire of those who consult the spirits and the fortune-tellers, who whisper and mutter,' should not a people inquire of their God? Should they seek the dead on behalf of the living?
verses.comment: Seeking guidance from mediums or occult practices is condemned. True revelation comes through God’s chosen means and His commissioned bearers of truth.

verses.text: To the law and to the testimony! If they do not speak according to this word, they have no dawn.
verses.comment: Scripture stands as the supreme norm. Those who depart from God’s revealed law and testimony walk in darkness—a foundational principle for spiritual discernment.

verses.text: They will pass through the land, greatly distressed and hungry; and when they are famished, they will become angry and curse their king and their God. They will look upward,
verses.comment: Those who reject God’s counsel endure hardship and spiritual famine, which leads not to repentance but to deeper rebellion—an observation repeated by the prophets and Jesus Himself.

verses.text: and they will look to the earth, but see only distress and darkness, gloom of anguish. They will be driven into thick darkness.
verses.comment: Separation from God results in spiritual darkness. However, this sets the stage for the prophecy of a coming great light (Isaiah 9:2; cf. Matt. 4:16), an early hint of the hope of redemption fulfilled in Christ.
